questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a small lump on the right side of her neck that she noticed while putting lotion on 1 week ago. She has not had any weight change, palpitations, or altered bowel habits. There is no family history of serious illness. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last for 4 days. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination shows a small nodule on the right side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is no lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasound of the neck shows a 0.9-cm (0.35-in) right lobe thyroid mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in determining the next step in management?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is indicated when malignancy is suspected in a thyroid nodule. Although this patient's ultrasound findings (e.g., a mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins) raise suspicion for malignancy, a different assessment is more helpful to determine whether FNA is warranted at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy can be used to remove the complete thyroid nodule or to obtain a better sample if fine-needle aspiration biopsy fails to provide clear results (e.g., because of an insufficient sample size). An open biopsy is not the most appropriate initial assessment.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy allows for classification of thyroid nodules based on the amount of radiotracer a nodule absorbs and is able to distinguish between hot and cold nodules. Although thyroid scintigraphy may be performed in the workup of thyroid nodules, a more basic functional assessment of the thyroid gland should be conducted first.

A hot or hyperfunctioning nodule contains thyroid hormone-producing cells and could result in hyperthyroidism, whereas a cold or nonfunctional nodule lacks thyroid hormone-producing cells and may indicate malignant neoplasia.

D) CORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) serum concentration and thyroid ultrasound should be performed in all patients with a suspected thyroid nodule to determine further management. If TSH levels are normal or elevated, this patient should undergo regular monitoring in case the tumor grows to ≥ 1 cm, in which case fine-needle aspiration biopsy would be indicated because of her suspicious ultrasound findings (i.e., a mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins). If TSH levels are subnormal, she should be evaluated for hyperthyroidism with thyroid scintigraphy.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

E) INCORRECT:

Although a CT scan of the neck is recommended for the staging of confirmed thyroid cancer, it is not suitable for the initial evaluation of patients with a thyroid nodule.
questions.hint: Thyroid function has not yet been assessed in this patient.

questions.text:
The patient is counseled about her risk of thyroid malignancy. Serum studies show:


Na+

138 mEq/L


K+

4.1 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


TSH
0.03 μU/mL


Calcium
9 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monitoring may be appropriate for thyroid nodules in which malignancy is not suspected and that do not meet criteria for immediate diagnostic procedures, e.g., nodules that are small (< 1 cm) in patients with no risk factors, nodules that are purely cystic, and nodules with a reassuring appearance on ultrasound. Periodic ultrasounds are performed to look for changes (e.g., enlargement), which should prompt further investigation if observed. However, this patient has a nodule with microcalcifications and irregular margins, which should raise suspicion of malignancy. Monitoring alone would not be appropriate for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Combined with low TSH, elevated free T4 and T3 levels are diagnostic of primary hyperthyroidism. This patient has low TSH levels, but none of the other symptoms expected in hyperthyroidism, such as weight loss, palpitations, and altered bowel habits. In addition, the functional status of the thyroid nodule should be evaluated, which does not include free T4 and T3 levels. If further diagnostic testing shows a hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule, assessment of free T4 and T3 levels may be appropriate at a later time to evaluate for subclinical hyperthyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) is typically used when there is suspicion of a malignant thyroid nodule. Suspicious features include a nodule with normal or elevated TSH (implying a decrease in thyroid function), a “cold” nodule on radionuclide scan, large nodules, clinical risk factors for malignancy, or sonographic characteristics such as an oval shape, calcifications, or irregular borders. This patient was found to have a thyroid mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins, which are features that should raise suspicion of malignancy. However, her low TSH points to hyperthyroidism and the possibility that the nodule may be hyperfunctioning (and therefore most likely benign), so further functional evaluation is indicated before proceeding to a minimally invasive procedure such as FNA biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy is relatively invasive and is therefore exclusively used when it is the only diagnostic procedure that can differentiate between a benign adenoma and malignant cancer, classically when differentiating follicular adenomas from carcinomas. While the sonographic appearance of this patient's nodule should raise suspicion of malignancy, there is not enough information to merit nodule excision as opposed to other, less invasive tests that would first determine the functional status or histological character of the nodule.

E) CORRECT:

A thyroid scintigraphy scan should be conducted in thyroid nodules associated with suppressed TSH to assess the functional status of the nodule and differentiate between hot and cold nodules. A hot nodule is characterized by increased radioiodine uptake, which suggests thyroid hyperfunction, and should be followed up by measuring free T3 and T4 levels to screen for hyperthyroidism. A cold nodule does not absorb radioiodine and may be consistent with thyroid malignancy. If ultrasound findings are suspicious for malignancy and the nodule is large enough (> 1 cm), a fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) is indicated. Nodules that are not appropriate for FNA should be closely monitored with repeat ultrasounds.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone
questions.hint: TSH is below normal in this patient, which means that further evaluation is required to characterize the functional status of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of palpitations and loose stools. She has had a 2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss over the past month. She has had no change in appetite. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She works in accounting and has been under more stress than usual lately. She appears pale. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bilateral hand tremor with outstretched arms and a palpable thyroid nodule in the left lobe. Serum laboratory studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.03 μU/mL and a thyroxine level of 28 μg/dL. A radioactive iodine uptake scan shows enhancement in a 3-cm encapsulated nodule in the lower left lobe with decreased uptake in the remaining gland. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid storm is typically caused by a sudden surge in thyroid hormones (e.g., discontinuation of antithyroid hormones) and is often precipitated by a stressor (e.g., surgery, sepsis). It manifests very acutely with hyperpyrexia, tachycardia, hypertension, nausea, vomiting, and severe agitation. While this patient also displays signs of hyperthyroidism, the onset of symptoms was not sufficiently acute and the presentation less severe than in thyroid storm, suggesting a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Riedel thyroiditis is associated with hypothyroidism and diffuse rock-like enlargement of the thyroid gland. This patient has a solitary palpable nodule on examination and presents with hyperthyroidism, which suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Papillary thyroid carcinomas may manifest as a single thyroid nodule on examination. Thyroid cancers typically display decreased radioactive iodine uptake, manifesting as “cold” nodules. However, in rare cases, a “hot” nodule with excess iodine uptake may be malignant. While a thyroid hormone-producing papillary carcinoma cannot be ruled out completely, another diagnosis is more likely in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism and is seen especially in young women. Patients with Graves disease typically present with a uniformly enlarged goiter that shows diffuse radioactive iodine uptake in the entire gland. This patient has a solitary palpable nodule on examination with enhanced iodine uptake, suggesting a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Toxic adenoma should be suspected in any patient presenting with signs of hyperthyroidism and a single palpable thyroid nodule with increased radioactive iodine uptake. In toxic adenoma, the synthetic function of the remainder of the gland is typically suppressed because of decreased TSH stimulation, resulting in decreased radioactive iodine uptake of the gland outside of the adenoma.
Image Description:

Overview of radioactive iodine uptake patterns in hyperthyroidism

Toxic MNG: Toxic multinodular goiter

F) INCORRECT:

Goiters can be associated with hyperthyroidism. However, an excess hormone-producing goiter indicates a hyperplastic response of the entire thyroid gland, which manifests as a multinodular thyroid on palpation and multiple areas of increased radioactive iodine uptake. A single palpable thyroid nodule with increased iodine uptake suggests another diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of palpitations, loose stools, and weight loss, as well as a decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and an increased thyroxin level, point to hyperthyroidism. The radioactive iodine uptake scan shows a single 'hot' nodule.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a slowly enlarging, painless neck mass. During this period, she has also experienced intermittent palpitations, hair loss, and a weight loss of 4.5 kg (10 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears anxious and fidgety. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 101/min and irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender left anterior cervical nodule that moves with swallowing. Laboratory studies show:


TSH
0.3 μU/mL


T4

13.2 μg/dL


T3

207 ng/dL


Ultrasonography confirms the presence of a 3-cm solid left thyroid nodule. A thyroid 123I radionuclide scintigraphy scan shows increased uptake in a nodule in the left lobe of the thyroid gland with suppression of the remainder of the thyroid tissue. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Thyroid peroxidase autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid tissue
Gain-of-function mutations of the TSH receptor
Persistent TSH stimulation and heterogeneous thyroid tissue hyperplasia
Stimulation of thyroid hormone release by TSH receptor autoantibodies
Activation of oncogenes promoting cell division

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Involution of a follicular adenoma causes a thyroid cyst to form. Thyroid cysts can be painful and cause symptoms secondary to mass effect and compression (e.g., hoarseness, dysphagia). Ultrasound would show a mass filled with fluid, not a solid mass. Additionally, patients with thyroid cysts do not generally present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, nor do they have abnormal thyroid function tests.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid tissue is seen in early Hashimoto thyroiditis. The initial destruction of thyroid tissue can lead to the release of thyroid hormones and subsequent transient hyperthyroidism (hashitoxicosis). However, patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis do not present with solid, solitary thyroid nodules. Additionally, the scintigraphy results are highly suggestive of a toxic adenoma.

C) CORRECT:

Toxic adenomas arise from a gain-of-function mutation in the TSH receptor gene that causes autonomous functioning of the TSH receptor independent of hypothalamic-pituitary regulation. Without negative feedback, the thyroid follicular cells become hyperplastic and eventually form a toxic adenoma. This autonomous thyroid nodule overproduces thyroid hormones, resulting in hyperthyroidism and a consequent decrease in pituitary TSH secretion. The remainder of the thyroid still responds appropriately to negative feedback, resulting in a suppressed appearance on scintigraphy.

D) INCORRECT:

Heterogenous thyroid tissue hyperplasia secondary to persistent TSH stimulation is the mechanism underlying toxic multinodular goiter. Though patients with toxic multinodular goiter also present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, they also tend to be older than > 60 years, have multiple nodules, and often have a history of iodine deficiency. In addition, scintigraphy of toxic multinodular goiter shows radioiodine uptake by multiple hyperfunctioning nodules rather than a single nodule as in toxic adenoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin antibody production would not cause a solitary, hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule. Some patients with other thyroid diseases (Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease, cancer) can present with anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, but these antibodies are a highly nonspecific finding of both thyroid and rheumatological diseases, including Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease, thyroid cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

F) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of thyroid hormone release by TSH receptor autoantibodies is the mechanism underlying Graves disease. Although patients with Graves disease present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, decreased TSH, and increased thyroid hormone levels, they rarely present with thyroid nodules.

G) INCORRECT:

Oncogene activation and consequent cell division is seen in thyroid cancer. Though hyperfunctioning cancer nodules can cause symptoms of hyperthyroidism, most thyroid cancers are asymptomatic. On examination, carcinomas tend to be fixed in place, rather than movable, as is the case in this patient. Additionally, the majority of thyroid cancers appear as cold, not hot, nodules on scintigraphy.

H) INCORRECT:

Patients with excessive exogenous thyroid hormone intake would also present with symptoms of hyperthyroidism and lab values similar to the patient in this case. However, the presence of a solitary nodule with increased uptake on scintigraphy would not be expected in the case of exogenous thyroid hormone intake.
questions.hint: This patient has signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, hair loss, and weight loss) with decreased TSH and increased T3 and T4 levels. These findings, combined with the presence of a solitary hot nodule on thyroid scintigraphy with suppression of surrounding thyroid tissue, imply that this patient has a toxic adenoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and a 5.4-kg (11.9-lb) weight loss over the past 3 months. She appears anxious. Her pulse is 104/min and blood pressure is 148/101 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm skin, mild tremor, and an enlarged thyroid gland. A thyroid scintigraphy scan shows several focal areas with increased uptake. A biopsy of one of these areas of affected thyroid tissue is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Sheets of parafollicular cells surrounded by amyloid stroma
Inflammatory infiltrate with multinucleated giant cells and granuloma formation
Follicle destruction with lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal center formation
Patches of enlarged follicular cells distended with colloid
Crowded follicular cells with scalloped colloid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sheets of parafollicular cells surrounded by amyloid stroma would be consistent with medullary carcinoma, a type of poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular C cells of the thyroid gland that typically arises sporadically but may be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Early symptoms tend to be mild, although some patients develop firm, painless thyroid nodules. In contrast to this patient, signs of hyperthyroidism would not be expected, and thyroid scintigraphy would not have increased uptake.

B) INCORRECT:

An inflammatory infiltrate with multinucleated giant cells and granuloma formation would be consistent with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (giant cell thyroiditis), a transient and self-resolving patchy inflammation of the thyroid gland that most commonly occurs after viral upper respiratory infection. The clinical course is typically triphasic, beginning first with hyperthyroidism, then hypothyroidism, and finally reaching a euthyroid state. In contrast to this patient, a diffuse decrease in radioiodine uptake would be expected on scintigraphy and this patient also lacks other classical clinical features such as tender goiter, elevated ESR, and jaw pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Follicle destruction with lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal center formation would be consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis. This is caused by autoantibody-mediated destruction of thyroid tissue, and manifests initially with hyperthyroidism, before progressing to hypothyroidism. The appearance of radioactive iodine uptake on scintigraphy is highly variable in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

D) CORRECT:

Focal patches of hyperfunctioning follicular cells are a histopathological feature of toxic multinodular goiter, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism after Graves disease. Toxic multinodular goiter is most commonly caused by chronic iodine deficiency, which decreases hormone production and thereby increases pituitary TSH secretion due to missing negative feedback. This leads to persistent stimulation of the thyroid gland, causing hyperplasia of thyroid nodules. In addition to the scintigraphy seen here, other characteristic findings include ↑ T3 and ↓ TSH. Scintigraphy is especially important when trying to differentiate between toxic multinodular goiter and Graves disease; in Graves disease, there is usually diffuse uptake on scintigraphy rather than focal areas of uptake.
Image Description:

Overview of radioactive iodine uptake patterns in hyperthyroidism

Toxic MNG: Toxic multinodular goiter

E) INCORRECT:

Crowded follicular cells with scalloped colloid would be consistent with Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Circulating TSH receptor autoantibodies trigger an overstimulation of the thyroid leading to excess thyroid hormone production. However, thyroid scintigraphy would show a diffuse uptake of radioactive iodine rather than the focal areas of increased uptake seen here. Furthermore, this patient is missing other classic signs of Graves disease such as ophthalmopathy and pretibial myxedema.
questions.hint: This patient presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism (palpitations, weight loss, warm skin, tremor) and a goiter. Her radioactive iodine scan shows several hyperfunctioning areas with increased uptake.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 15 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because she noticed swelling of her neck 2 weeks ago. Her neck does not hurt and she does not have difficulty swallowing. She has had occasional nausea and decreased appetite during the past few weeks but otherwise feels well. She has had appropriate weight gain for her gestational age. Medical history is remarkable for recurrent cystitis. She smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years but quit 8 years ago. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/71 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm firm, nodular mass on the left side of her throat. There are no overlying skin changes or cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The uterine fundus is palpable midway between the symphysis and umbilicus. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8000 /mm3



Platelet count
230,000 /mm3



Serum



 Na+

140 mEq/L


 K+

4.1 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 Ca2+

9.2 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL


 TSH

3.0 μU/mL


 Free T4

1.1 ng/dL


Ultrasonography of the thyroid shows a solid 1.6-cm mass in the left lobe with hyper- and hypoechoic parts. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen concentrations

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Follow-up after delivery would be appropriate for a benign thyroid nodule. However, this patient's ultrasonography findings raise concern for malignancy. Because the prognosis of thyroid cancer is greatly improved by early identification and treatment, this patient requires further evaluation at this time.

B) CORRECT:

All patients with thyroid nodules are evaluated with TSH level measurement and thyroid ultrasonography. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) should be performed in patients with normal or high TSH and ultrasonographic findings that raise concern for malignancy. Pregnancy is not a contraindication for FNA. Benign thyroid nodules (e.g., follicular adenoma, thyroid cyst) are distinguished from malignant types (e.g., carcinoma, lymphoma, metastases) using FNA cytopathology findings. The Bethesda system is then used to further classify the nodule, which determines the subsequent management steps.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen concentration is used to monitor treatment response and screen for disease recurrence in patients with confirmed medullary carcinoma. It is not, however, performed for the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule because of its low specificity in the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is performed in patients with thyroid nodules who also have low TSH levels, while this patient's TSH is normal. Moreover, radiation is teratogenic and thyroid scintigraphy is, therefore, contraindicated in pregnancy.
Image Description:

Overview of radioactive iodine uptake patterns in hyperthyroidism

Toxic MNG: Toxic multinodular goiter

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum thyroglobulin is indicated in patients with follicular or papillary thyroid cancer who have undergone treatment, in order to screen for residual or recurrent disease. It is not, however, included in the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule because of its low specificity in the diagnosis of follicular and papillary thyroid cancers.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient's ultrasonography findings (i.e., thyroid nodule of ≥ 1 cm in diameter with hypoechoic parts) raise concern for malignancy.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman being seen for follow-up of hypertension reports that she has noticed a swelling in the anterior triangle of her neck during the past 12 to 18 months. She has not experienced any weight loss, weight gain, palpitations, muscle weakness, skin changes, voice changes, or neck pain. She has no personal history of radiation exposure and no family history of thyroid cancer.
On physical examination, her blood pressure is 142/87 mm Hg, her heart rate is 92 beats per minute, and her temperature is 36.5°C. She has a 2- to 3-cm swelling at the base of the neck, just to the right of the trachea. The swelling moves superiorly when she swallows. There is no tenderness or tethering to the skin and no lymphadenopathy. The patient’s palms are slightly diaphoretic, but the physical examination is otherwise normal, with no sign of thyroid dysfunction.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Thyroid-stimulating hormone (μU/mL)
0.03
0.5–4.7


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.4
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
3.6
3.0–4.5


Albumin (g/dL)
3.8
3.5–5.5


The results of a complete blood count are normal.
What is the best next step for evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Thyroid ultrasound and fine-needle aspiration of the nodule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT imaging can clarify the structural abnormalities, but it does not provide functional information.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin levels can be elevated in Graves disease but are not the best measure of autonomy of the nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

If a nodule ≥ 1 cm is not taking up the radiotracer (a “cold” nodule), it should be evaluated by means of ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration to rule out malignancy.

D) CORRECT:

Thyroid nodules are common, especially in older adults. A key determination is whether the nodule is hyperfunctioning (or “hot”), which is associated with a low (< 5%) risk of malignancy. Radionuclide scanning involving either iodine-123 or Tc-99m is required to determine whether a nodule is hyperfunctioning and therefore taking up the radiotracer to a greater extent than the surrounding thyroid gland. The use of iodine is preferred over Tc-99m when the diagnostic scan is performed in preparation for therapeutic radioactive iodine ablation of the hyperfunctioning nodule.

If the nodule is hyperfunctioning, the risk of malignancy is sufficiently low to obviate the need for a fine-needle aspiration, although the hyperthyroidism should be treated with antithyroid drugs or with thyroid ablation using radioactive iodine.

Key learning point: The best next step to evaluate a thyroid nodule >1 cm in diameter in a patient with a low thyroid-stimulating hormone level is to order a radionuclide scan with either iodine-123 or Tc-99m.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

E) INCORRECT:

Sestamibi scanning is helpful in localizing a parathyroid adenoma, but it does not provide information about the functional status of a thyroid nodule.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 14-year-old girl presents with a right-sided neck mass, noted one month ago. She has had no pain, erythema, difficulty swallowing, fevers, or voice changes.
Physical examination reveals a nodule measuring approximately 2 cm over the right lobe of the thyroid gland without any regional lymphadenopathy. The patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.5 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.0). Ultrasound reveals a 1.8-cm hypoechoic nodule with microcalcifications in the right thyroid nodule and no lymphadenopathy.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Repeat thyroid ultrasound in 3 to 6 months
Measure serum thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral for thyroid lobectomy is not indicated at this time. The results of the fine-needle aspiration will determine if the lesion is benign or not, and this will help guide further evaluation and surgical planning as necessary.

B) CORRECT:

Thyroid nodules are relatively uncommon in children, but the proportion that are malignant is likely to be higher in children than in adults (22%–26% versus 5%–10%), thus necessitating a higher level of suspicion. Children with thyroid cancer tend to have more extensive disease at presentation than adults do (lymph node metastasis, pulmonary metastasis), but their risk of long-term cancer-specific mortality (≤2%) is lower.

When a thyroid nodule is detected on imaging or physical examination, the first step is to measure the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level. In rare cases, an autonomous thyroid nodule can cause mild hyperthyroidism, yielding a low TSH level. If the TSH level is normal (as in this case), the next step is to further characterize the nodule on ultrasound. There are not specific laboratory tests that can discern whether the nodule is benign or malignant.

Specific clinical guidelines exist for the management of thyroid nodules in children. Various scoring systems have been developed to stratify the need for fine-needle aspiration (FNA); however, increasing evidence shows that nodule size alone does not warrant FNA in pediatrics. If the nodule shows concerning features (such as hypoechogenicity, irregular margins, a height greater than its width, increased vascularity, or calcifications), then ultrasound-guided FNA should be performed, regardless of whether regional lymphadenopathy is present. This patient’s nodule had microcalcifications on ultrasound and therefore warrants further evaluation with FNA.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in the evaluation of a suspicious thyroid nodule detected on imaging or physical examination in a patient with a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level is ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat thyroid ultrasound in 3 to 6 months would not be appropriate, as this nodule is suspicious and requires further investigation promptly.

D) INCORRECT:

Nuclear scintigraphy would be appropriate in a patient with a thyroid nodule who had a suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level, to determine whether the nodule was hyperfunctioning; if so, it could be surgically removed. This patient’s TSH level is normal, so nuclear scintigraphy would not be appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated thyroid antibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase are seen in the setting of autoimmune thyroid disease, which can be associated with goiter; however, this patient has a distinct nodule, which requires further evaluation for cytology, and measurement of antibody levels would not be the most appropriate next step.

Benign thyroid nodules (e.g., follicular adenoma, thyroid cyst) are distinguished from malignant types (e.g., carcinoma, lymphoma, metastases) using FNA cytopathology findings. The Bethesda system is then used to further classify the nodule, which determines the subsequent management steps.

Key learning point: A thyroid nodule with suspicious ultrasound features and normal TSH should be evaluated with fine-needle aspiration, even during pregnancy, to rule out malignancy.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen concentration is used to monitor treatment response and screen for disease recurrence in patients with confirmed medullary carcinoma. It is not, however, performed for the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule because of its low specificity in the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is performed in patients with thyroid nodules who also have low TSH levels, while this patient's TSH is normal. Moreover, radiation is teratogenic and thyroid scintigraphy is, therefore, contraindicated in pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum thyroglobulin is indicated in patients with follicular or papillary thyroid cancer who have undergone treatment, in order to screen for residual or recurrent disease. It is not, however, included in the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule because of its low specificity in the diagnosis of follicular and papillary thyroid cancers.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient's ultrasonography findings (i.e., thyroid nodule of ≥ 1 cm in diameter with hypoechoic parts) raise concern for malignancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a small lump on the right side of her neck that she noticed while putting lotion on 1 week ago. She has not had any weight change, palpitations, or altered bowel habits. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last for 4 days. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination shows a small nodule on the right side of the neck that moves with swallowing. There is no lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in determining the next step in management?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the swelling

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy is indicated when malignancy is suspected in a thyroid nodule. Another step in management is indicated at this time to help determine the necessity of an FNA.

B) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy can be used to remove the complete thyroid nodule or to obtain a better sample if fine-needle aspiration biopsy fails to provide clear results (e.g., because of an insufficient sample size). An open biopsy is not the most appropriate initial assessment.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy allows for classification of thyroid nodules based on the amount of radiotracer a nodule absorbs and is able to distinguish between hot and cold nodules. Although thyroid scintigraphy may be performed in the workup of thyroid nodules, a more basic functional assessment of the thyroid gland should be conducted first.

A hot or hyperfunctioning nodule contains thyroid hormone-producing cells and could result in hyperthyroidism, whereas a cold or nonfunctional nodule lacks thyroid hormone-producing cells and may indicate malignant neoplasia.

D) CORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) serum concentration and thyroid ultrasound should be performed in all patients with a suspected thyroid nodule to determine further management. If TSH levels are normal or elevated, this patient should undergo regular monitoring in case the tumor grows to ≥ 1 cm, in which case fine-needle aspiration biopsy would be indicated because of her suspicious ultrasound findings. If TSH levels are subnormal, she should be evaluated for hyperthyroidism with thyroid scintigraphy.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

E) INCORRECT:

Although a CT scan of the neck is recommended for the staging of confirmed thyroid cancer, it is not suitable for the initial evaluation of patients with a thyroid nodule.
questions.hint: Thyroid function has not yet been assessed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of palpitations, weight loss, and intermittent tremor. She denies neck pain, prior neck radiation, and has no personal or family history of thyroid disease. Physical examination reveals a solitary, firm, 2-cm nodule in the right thyroid lobe without cervical lymphadenopathy, exophthalmos, or pretibial myxedema. She reports no compressive symptoms (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
0.10 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
18 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L



Thyroid ultrasound: Solid nodule with no suspicious features
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this thyroid nodule?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies evaluate autoimmune thyroid disorders, such as Hashimoto thyroiditis, which typically presents with a diffuse gland. The patient's solitary nodule and hyperthyroidism suggest the need to assess the nodule's function rather than investigate an autoimmune process.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum calcitonin helps identify medullary thyroid carcinoma, which does not cause hyperthyroidism. The patient's symptoms and lab findings suggest a hyperfunctioning nodule, not a calcitonin-producing tumor. The absence of suspicious ultrasound features and family history further reduces the likelihood of medullary carcinoma.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with hyperthyroidism, indicated by suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and elevated free thyroxine (T4), and a solitary thyroid nodule, a thyroid radionuclide scan is essential to assess the nodule's functional status. This scan differentiates between hyperfunctioning (hot) and nonfunctioning (cold) nodules. Hyperfunctioning nodules take up more radiotracer, confirming them as the source of excess hormone production. The risk of malignancy in hot nodules is low, reducing the need for invasive procedures like fine-needle aspiration biopsy unless suspicious features are present.

Key learning point: In the evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule with hyperthyroidism, thyroid isotope scintigraphy is the appropriate next step to determine if the nodule is functioning ('hot') or non-functioning ('cold').

D) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is used for thyroid nodules suspicious for malignancy. However, in hyperthyroid patients, nodules are often autonomously functioning (hot) and less likely to be malignant. The patient's suppressed TSH and elevated free T4 suggest hyperthyroidism, making functional imaging a more appropriate initial step.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents with a neck mass noticed two months ago. She is otherwise healthy and denies dysphagia or voice changes. Physical examination reveals a single, 2-cm, firm nodule in the right thyroid lobe. Laboratory evaluation, including TSH, is within normal limits (see report).
Ultrasound of the neck: Solid nodule with irregular borders; no detectable cervical lymphadenopathy
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for possible malignancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial ultrasound follow-up is suitable for nodules with benign characteristics, such as smooth margins, which lower malignancy risk. However, a 2-cm solid nodule with irregular borders raises concern for malignancy, necessitating immediate evaluation rather than delayed monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Radioactive iodine uptake scans assess nodule function, identifying hyperfunctioning nodules, which are usually benign. This patient has normal thyroid function tests, ruling out hyperthyroidism. The solid nodule with irregular borders suggests malignancy, warranting tissue sampling rather than functional imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum calcitonin measurement is primarily for evaluating medullary thyroid carcinoma, associated with elevated calcitonin levels. This patient's nodule has features more typical of papillary thyroid carcinoma, and there is no indication of medullary thyroid carcinoma, making calcitonin measurement unnecessary.

D) CORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is essential for evaluating thyroid nodules with suspicious ultrasound features, such as solid composition and irregular borders, which increase the likelihood of malignancy. This procedure provides cytologic samples to differentiate between benign and malignant lesions, guiding further management. It is performed under ultrasound guidance to enhance accuracy and minimize complications. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is crucial for early detection of thyroid cancers, including papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common type encountered clinically.

Key learning point: For a 2 cm solid thyroid nodule, fine needle aspiration is the best next step to evaluate for malignancy.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a painless swelling on the right side of her neck discovered incidentally. She denies hoarseness, dysphagia, or changes in energy levels. She has no family history of thyroid disease or prior radiation exposure and takes no medications besides a daily multivitamin. Physical examination shows a firm, non-tender thyroid nodule measuring approximately 2 cm in diameter (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.0 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
14 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L



Neck ultrasound: 1.8 cm predominantly hypoechoic nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications; no evident cervical lymphadenopathy
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radionuclide thyroid scans assess nodule functionality, particularly in cases of low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suggesting hyperfunctioning nodules. This patient has normal TSH levels, indicating euthyroidism, and ultrasound features suggestive of malignancy, reducing the utility of a radionuclide scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate total thyroidectomy is considered when malignancy is confirmed. This nodule has suspicious features but lacks a pathological diagnosis. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is necessary to confirm malignancy before considering surgery, avoiding unnecessary surgical risks.

C) CORRECT:

Thyroid nodules with features such as hypoechogenicity, irregular margins, and microcalcifications on ultrasound are suspicious for malignancy. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) is the preferred diagnostic procedure for such nodules, especially those greater than 1 cm, as it allows for cytological evaluation to differentiate between benign and malignant lesions. This patient has normal thyroid function tests, making FNA the appropriate next step to guide management based on cytopathological findings.

Key learning point: For thyroid nodules with suspicious ultrasound features, such as hypoechoic appearance and microcalcifications, fine-needle aspiration is the appropriate next step to assess for malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Annual ultrasound follow-up is suitable for nodules with benign characteristics. This nodule has suspicious features, including hypoechogenicity, irregular margins, and microcalcifications, and measures nearly 2 cm, warranting immediate diagnostic evaluation rather than surveillance.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents with a solitary 1.5 cm right thyroid nodule identified on routine neck ultrasound. She has no symptoms of hyper- or hypothyroidism and no other significant medical history. Physical examination reveals a mobile, firm mass in the right lobe without cervical lymphadenopathy. Serum TSH is within normal limits. Fine needle aspiration of the nodule was performed, but the specimen was nondiagnostic due to insufficient cellularity (see reports).

Neck ultrasound: Solitary 1.5 cm right thyroid nodule
Fine needle aspiration: Nondiagnostic due to insufficient cellularity

What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat fine needle aspiration under ultrasound guidance

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine therapy aims to suppress TSH to reduce nodule growth. However, in euthyroid patients with nondiagnostic FNA, guidelines advise against it. Normal TSH indicates no overactivity, and suppression risks subclinical hyperthyroidism, causing arrhythmias and bone density loss. Levothyroxine does not consistently reduce nodule size or improve cytology.

B) INCORRECT:

Radionuclide thyroid scans assess nodule function, especially with abnormal thyroid function tests. In euthyroid patients, these scans do not inform malignancy risk. They are useful for identifying autonomously functioning nodules, which are less likely malignant. With normal TSH and nondiagnostic biopsy, focus should be on obtaining a conclusive tissue diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Nondiagnostic fine needle aspiration (FNA) samples are common in thyroid nodule evaluations. Ultrasound guidance enhances specimen adequacy by ensuring precise needle placement into the nodule's solid component, reducing sampling error. For nodules over 1 cm, a repeat FNA is preferred over invasive procedures. This approach aligns with guidelines to avoid missing potential malignancies while minimizing unnecessary surgeries. Ultrasound-guided FNA optimizes cellularity, increasing the likelihood of a definitive cytological diagnosis.

Key learning point: In cases of thyroid nodules with inadequate fine needle aspiration results, repeating the FNA is crucial for obtaining an adequate cytological evaluation to guide further management.

D) INCORRECT:

Total thyroidectomy involves complete thyroid removal and is reserved for confirmed malignancy, multifocal disease, or bilateral involvement. The solitary 1.5 cm nodule lacks aggressive features like cervical lymphadenopathy. A nondiagnostic FNA prompts repeat sampling, not immediate surgery. Total thyroidectomy risks, such as recurrent laryngeal nerve and parathyroid injury, are unwarranted without confirmed cancer.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine checkup. She reports mild fatigue for the past few months but denies neck pain, dysphagia, or voice changes. She has no significant past medical history, history of radiation exposure, or family history of thyroid malignancy. Physical examination identifies a small thyroid nodule in the right lobe. Cervical lymph nodes appear normal (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.1 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroid ultrasound: 0.9 cm well-defined, hypoechoic lesion without suspicious features such as microcalcifications or irregular margins
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A radionuclide thyroid scan is used to evaluate nodules in the context of suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone levels, suggesting hyperfunctioning nodules. This patient has normal thyroid function, and the nodule lacks suspicious features, making the scan unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration biopsy is indicated for thyroid nodules that are 1 cm or larger or exhibit suspicious features. The 0.9 cm nodule lacks high-risk characteristics such as microcalcifications or irregular margins, and the patient has no high-risk clinical factors. Therefore, a biopsy is not warranted.

C) CORRECT:

The thyroid nodule is 0.9 cm, well-defined, and hypoechoic without suspicious features such as microcalcifications or irregular margins, suggesting benignity. Current guidelines recommend active surveillance with serial ultrasounds for nodules under 1 cm lacking high-risk characteristics, as the malignancy risk is low. With a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone level, further rapid diagnostic intervention is unnecessary. Monitoring with repeat ultrasound in 6-12 months allows for detection of any changes in the nodule's characteristics, ensuring appropriate management while avoiding unnecessary invasive procedures.

Key learning point: For small thyroid nodules (<1 cm) without suspicious features on ultrasound, follow-up imaging is appropriate to monitor for changes, while fine needle aspiration is reserved for larger or suspicious nodules.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

D) INCORRECT:

Hemithyroidectomy is reserved for confirmed or highly suspected thyroid malignancy or nodules with high-risk features. The nodule is small, well-defined, and lacks suspicious characteristics, and the patient has no high-risk factors, making surgical intervention unnecessarily aggressive.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman presents with 5 months of weight loss, palpitations, and hand tremors. She resides in a region with a history of dietary iodine deficiency and reports intermittent neck swelling over the past decade. She denies neck pain. Her thyroid gland is non-tender with multiple nodules. She notices occasional palpitations at rest. There is no conjunctival injection or proptosis (see lab results).

Heart rate
112/min



Test
Result
Normal Values



Thyroid-stimulating hormone
< 0.01 mIU/L
0.4 - 5.0 mIU/L


Thyroxine (T4 free)
42 pmol/L
8.5 - 15.2 pmol/L


TSH receptor antibodies
Negative
Negative



Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hyperthyroidism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graves disease typically presents with a diffusely enlarged thyroid, positive TSH receptor antibodies, and ocular manifestations such as conjunctival injection and proptosis. This patient has a multinodular thyroid without ocular findings and negative TSH receptor antibodies, making Graves disease unlikely. Her history of iodine deficiency and intermittent neck swelling suggests nodular thyroid changes rather than the diffuse hyperplasia seen in Graves disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (painless thyroiditis) involves transient hyperthyroidism due to the release of preformed thyroid hormones from an inflamed gland, usually presenting with a diffusely enlarged thyroid. It is more common in younger women, especially postpartum. This patient, however, has a multinodular thyroid and a history of iodine deficiency, indicating a chronic nodular process rather than transient inflammation.

C) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits symptoms of thyrotoxicosis, including weight loss, palpitations, and tremors, with laboratory findings of suppressed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and elevated free thyroxine (T4). Her history of living in an iodine-deficient region suggests chronic thyroid stimulation, leading to the development of multiple nodules. These nodules can become autonomously functioning, producing thyroid hormone independently of TSH. The absence of ocular manifestations and negative TSH receptor antibodies, along with a non-tender, multinodular thyroid gland, align with toxic multinodular goiter, a condition resulting from long-standing iodine deficiency.

Key learning point: In a patient with hyperthyroid symptoms and a non-tender goiter, negative thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins suggest toxic nodular goiter rather than Graves' disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Exogenous thyrotoxicosis results from exogenous thyroid hormone ingestion, leading to suppressed TSH and elevated thyroid hormone levels. The thyroid gland typically appears normal or atrophic, without nodular changes. This patient has a multinodular thyroid and a history of iodine deficiency, suggesting endogenous thyroid overactivity rather than exogenous hormone ingestion.

questions.text:
You are counseling a patient about her risk of thyroid malignancy. Serum studies show the following:


Sodium (Na), blood
138 mmol/L (136–146)


Potassium (K), blood
4.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Chloride (Cl), blood
101 mmol/L (98–107)


Thyrotropin (thyroid-stimulating hormone), blood

0.03 mIU/L (0.34–5.60)


Calcium (Ca), total, blood
2.25 mmol/L (2.12–2.52)


Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A thyroid scintigraphy scan should be conducted in thyroid nodules associated with suppressed TSH to assess the functional status of the nodule and differentiate between hot and cold nodules. A hot nodule is characterized by increased radioiodine uptake, which suggests thyroid hyperfunction, and should be followed up by measuring free T3 and T4 levels to screen for hyperthyroidism. A cold nodule does not absorb radioiodine and may be consistent with thyroid malignancy. If ultrasound findings are suspicious for malignancy and the nodule is large enough (> 1 cm), a fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) is indicated. Nodules that are not appropriate for FNA should be closely monitored with repeat ultrasounds.

Key learning point: A thyroid nodule with suppressed TSH should be evaluated first with a thyroid scintigraphy scan to determine if it is hyperfunctioning (“hot”) or nonfunctioning (“cold”), guiding further management and malignancy risk assessment.
Image Description:

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

B) INCORRECT:

An open biopsy is relatively invasive and is therefore exclusively used when it is the only diagnostic procedure that can differentiate between a benign adenoma and malignant cancer, classically when differentiating follicular adenomas from carcinomas. While the sonographic appearance of this patient's nodule should raise suspicion of malignancy, there is not enough information to merit nodule excision as opposed to other, less invasive tests that would first determine the functional status or histological character of the nodule.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) is typically used when there is suspicion of a malignant thyroid nodule. Suspicious features include a nodule with normal or elevated TSH (implying a decrease in thyroid function), a “cold” nodule on radionuclide scan, large nodules, clinical risk factors for malignancy, or sonographic characteristics such as an oval shape, calcifications, or irregular borders. This patient was found to have a thyroid mass with microcalcifications and irregular margins, which are features that should raise suspicion of malignancy. However, her low TSH points to hyperthyroidism and the possibility that the nodule may be hyperfunctioning (and therefore most likely benign), so further functional evaluation is indicated before proceeding to a minimally invasive procedure such as FNA biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Monitoring may be appropriate for thyroid nodules in which malignancy is not suspected and that do not meet criteria for immediate diagnostic procedures, e.g., nodules that are small (< 1 cm) in patients with no risk factors, nodules that are purely cystic, and nodules with a reassuring appearance on ultrasound. Periodic ultrasounds are performed to look for changes (e.g., enlargement), which should prompt further investigation if observed. However, this patient has a nodule with microcalcifications and irregular margins, which should raise suspicion of malignancy. Monitoring alone would not be appropriate for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined with low TSH, elevated free T4 and T3 levels are diagnostic of primary hyperthyroidism. This patient has low TSH levels, but none of the other symptoms expected in hyperthyroidism, such as weight loss, palpitations, and altered bowel habits. In addition, the functional status of the thyroid nodule should be evaluated, which does not include free T4 and T3 levels. If further diagnostic testing shows a hyperfunctioning thyroid nodule, assessment of free T4 and T3 levels may be appropriate at a later time to evaluate for subclinical hyperthyroidism.
questions.hint: TSH is below normal in this patient, which means that further evaluation is required to characterize the functional status of the thyroid.

questions.text: You are seeing a 32-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 15 weeks' gestation who presents with a 2-week history of neck swelling. She reports no pain or difficulty swallowing. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a 1.5-cm firm, nodular mass on the left side of her neck. Laboratory studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 3.0 mIU/L (0.34–5.60) and a free thyroxine level of 14.2 pmol/L (7.0–17.0). Thyroid ultrasonography reveals a solid 1.6-cm mass in the left lobe with both hyper- and hypoechoic areas. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen concentrations.

It is not, however, included in the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule because of its low specificity in the diagnosis of follicular and papillary thyroid cancers.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is performed in patients with thyroid nodules who also have low TSH levels, while this patient's TSH is normal. Moreover, radiation is teratogenic and thyroid scintigraphy is, therefore, contraindicated in pregnancy.

Measurement of serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen concentration is used to monitor treatment response and screen for disease recurrence in patients with confirmed medullary carcinoma. It is not, however, performed for the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule because of its low specificity in the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Follow-up after delivery would be appropriate for a benign thyroid nodule. However, this patient's ultrasonography findings raise concern for malignancy. Because the prognosis of thyroid cancer is greatly improved by early identification and treatment, this patient requires further evaluation at this time.

E) CORRECT:

All patients with thyroid nodules are evaluated with TSH level measurement and thyroid ultrasonography. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) should be performed in patients with normal or high TSH and ultrasonographic findings that raise concern for malignancy. Pregnancy is not a contraindication for FNA. Benign thyroid nodules (e.g., follicular adenoma, thyroid cyst) are distinguished from malignant types (e.g., carcinoma, lymphoma, metastases) using FNA cytopathology findings. questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-month history of a gradually enlarging neck mass. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm firm, mobile nodule in the left thyroid lobe. Initial laboratory studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level of 2.8 mIU/L (normal range 0.4–4.0 mIU/L). Thyroid ultrasound shows a solid, hypoechoic nodule with irregular margins and punctate echogenic foci consistent with microcalcifications. No cervical lymphadenopathy is present. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the neck with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is indicated for patients with low TSH levels to identify hyperfunctioning nodules; this patient has a normal TSH level.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation with repeat imaging is inappropriate because this patient has a solid hypoechoic nodule with high-risk sonographic signs of thyroid malignancy, including irregular margins and microcalcifications.

C) INCORRECT:

CT scan is not part of the standard diagnostic workup for thyroid nodules; ultrasound provides more detailed information about thyroid anatomy and nodule characteristics.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has several indications for fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of thyroid nodules. FNAC is indicated for all solid hypoechoic nodules ≥ 1 cm with or without additional sonographic signs of thyroid cancer. Signs such as irregular margins or microcalcifications are considered a high-risk pattern, with an estimated malignancy risk > 10%.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum calcitonin is reserved for patients in whom medullary carcinoma is suspected based on cytology findings or family history. Calcitonin is not indicated as an initial diagnostic test for thyroid nodules.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath. She is clinically stable. A chest CT angiogram (CTA) is obtained to rule out pulmonary embolism (PE). The CTA is negative for PE, but the radiologist reports an incidental 1.2-cm solid thyroid nodule in the left lobe. The patient does not have any symptoms suggestive of a thyroid disorder. She has no palpable thyroid enlargement or lymphadenopathy. What is the most appropriate outpatient follow-up recommendation for this incidental thyroid nodule?

choices.text: Recommend checking thyroid-stimulating hormone level and obtaining a thyroid ultrasound

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Recommending no further workup is inappropriate because all thyroid nodules, including incidentalomas discovered during imaging for unrelated causes, should be evaluated for malignancy. Although the majority of thyroid nodules are benign, approximately 5% are malignant.

B) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not the initial step in thyroid nodule evaluation. FNAC is indicated only after initial evaluation with thyroid-stimulating hormone levels and thyroid ultrasound if specific criteria are met.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The initial evaluation of all thyroid nodules, including incidentalomas, includes thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels and thyroid ultrasound. This approach allows for stratifying risk appropriately and determining whether further testing with fine-needle aspiration cytology is indicated based on sonographic features and TSH results.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid scintigraphy is only indicated for thyroid nodules in patients with low levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) to identify hyperfunctioning nodules. Because this patient's TSH level is unknown, scintigraphy is not the initial step in evaluation and should be considered only after TSH results are available.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct endocrinology referral without initial testing bypasses the standard evaluation approach. Thyroid-stimulating hormone levels and thyroid ultrasound should be obtained first to guide appropriate specialist referral and provide the endocrinologist with essential baseline information for further management decisions.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents for an annual wellness examination. She reports no neck pain, dysphagia, or hoarseness. Her medical history is significant only for well-controlled hypertension. She denies any changes in weight, mood, or temperature preference. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender, 2-cm nodule is palpated in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. The remainder of her examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies were ordered, and her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is 2.5 mIU/L (reference range 0.4-4.0 mIU/L). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient's condition?

choices.text: CT scan of the neck with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A radionuclide thyroid scan (thyroid scintigraphy) is primarily indicated for the evaluation of a thyroid nodule when the TSH level is low (suppressed). This test helps determine if the nodule is hyperfunctioning ("hot") or non-functioning ("cold"). Since this patient's TSH level is normal, a scan is not the appropriate next step.

B) INCORRECT:

While a CT scan can visualize the thyroid gland and surrounding structures, it is not the preferred initial imaging modality for evaluating a thyroid nodule. Furthermore, the iodinated contrast used in CT scans can interfere with potential future radionuclide scanning or radioactive iodine treatment if a malignancy is diagnosed. A CT scan is typically reserved for assessing large, complex goiters with substernal extension or for staging known advanced thyroid cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is the most accurate test to differentiate between benign and malignant thyroid nodules. However, it is not the initial step after a physical exam and TSH measurement. Performing FNA on all palpable nodules would lead to unnecessary procedures.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum thyroglobulin is a protein produced by thyroid follicular cells and can be elevated in various thyroid conditions, including both benign goiters and thyroid cancer. Due to its lack of specificity, it is not recommended for the initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule. Its primary clinical utility is as a tumor marker to monitor for recurrence in patients who have undergone thyroidectomy for differentiated thyroid cancer.

E) CORRECT:

In a patient with a palpable thyroid nodule and a normal or elevated TSH level, thyroid ultrasonography is the recommended initial imaging study. It is highly sensitive for confirming the presence of the nodule, determining its size, and characterizing its features, such as composition (solid, cystic, or mixed), echogenicity, margins, and the presence of calcifications. These sonographic findings are essential for malignancy risk stratification, often using systems like the ACR Thyroid Imaging Reporting & Data System. The results of the ultrasound guide the decision of whether to proceed with fine-needle aspiration (FNA). For instance, a 2-cm nodule with highly suspicious features (e.g., microcalcifications, irregular margins) would warrant FNA, while a purely cystic nodule might be monitored.
questions.hint: The patient's normal TSH level is a key finding that directs the next step in the diagnostic algorithm for a thyroid nodule.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is referred for evaluation of a thyroid nodule discovered incidentally on a carotid artery ultrasound. She is asymptomatic and denies any changes in voice or swallowing difficulties. Her mother was treated for papillary thyroid cancer. Her TSH level is 2.1 mU/L (normal 0.4-4.0). A subsequent thyroid ultrasound reveals a solid, 1.8 cm, hypoechoic nodule in the right lobe with irregular margins and internal microcalcifications. There is no associated cervical lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the nodule

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A radionuclide thyroid scan is used to assess the functional status of a thyroid nodule, typically in the setting of a low or suppressed TSH level. This test determines if a nodule is hyperfunctioning ("hot") or non-functioning ("cold"). Since this patient's TSH is normal, a radionuclide scan is not indicated as the next step in the diagnostic algorithm.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's thyroid nodule has multiple high-risk features for malignancy on ultrasound, including solid composition, hypoechogenicity, irregular margins, and microcalcifications. Given these findings in a nodule >1 cm and a family history of papillary thyroid cancer, the next step is to obtain a cytologic diagnosis. Ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is the gold standard procedure for evaluating suspicious thyroid nodules. The results, classified by the Bethesda system, will guide further management, which may range from observation to surgical intervention. A normal TSH level indicates the patient is euthyroid, making FNA the most appropriate next step over functional imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum calcitonin is a tumor marker for medullary thyroid cancer. While some institutions perform routine calcitonin screening for all thyroid nodules, it is not the primary diagnostic step for a nodule with sonographic features more typical of papillary thyroid cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision is a therapeutic intervention, not the initial diagnostic step for a thyroid nodule. While surgery may be indicated if malignancy is confirmed, proceeding directly to lobectomy without confirming the diagnosis is not an appropriate management step at this point.

E) INCORRECT:

Active surveillance with serial ultrasounds is an appropriate strategy for small, low-risk thyroid nodules or nodules with benign cytology on FNA. However, this patient's nodule has multiple sonographic features that are highly suspicious for malignancy. Therefore, delaying diagnosis with observation is not appropriate, and a definitive diagnostic procedure is warranted.
questions.hint: The combination of a normal TSH and irregular margins and microcalcifications on ultrasound is highly suspicious for malignancy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of unintentional weight loss and palpitations. Her medical history is significant for hypertension. On examination, her pulse is 108/min and irregular, and her blood pressure is 145/88 mm Hg. A single, firm, non-tender 2-cm nodule is palpated in the right lobe of the thyroid. The remainder of the gland is not enlarged. There is no exophthalmos or pretibial myxedema. Laboratory studies show a TSH level of <0.01 mU/L and an elevated free T4. A radioactive iodine uptake scan reveals a focal area of intense tracer accumulation in the right lobe with suppressed uptake throughout the rest of the gland. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation of hyperthyroidism, including suppressed TSH and elevated free T4, is caused by a toxic adenoma. This condition involves a solitary, autonomous thyroid nodule that produces excess thyroid hormone independent of TSH stimulation. The diagnosis is confirmed by the physical examination finding of a single palpable nodule and the classic radioactive iodine uptake scan, which shows focal intense uptake (a "hot" nodule) corresponding to the adenoma. The high levels of circulating thyroid hormone exert negative feedback on the pituitary, leading to TSH suppression and consequently decreased uptake in the normal surrounding thyroid tissue. The absence of ophthalmopathy and dermopathy further suggests that autoimmune causes are unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Struma ovarii is a rare condition where an ovarian teratoma contains functional thyroid tissue, causing hyperthyroidism. While it would cause hyperthyroid symptoms and a suppressed TSH, the thyroid gland in the neck would be normal on palpation and would show very low or absent uptake on a radioactive iodine scan because the hormone is produced ectopically. This patient has a palpable thyroid nodule with focal high uptake in the neck.

C) INCORRECT:

While toxic multinodular goiter also causes hyperthyroidism through autonomous nodules, it involves multiple nodules rather than a single one. The physical exam would reveal a multinodular goiter, and the radioactive iodine uptake scan would show multiple areas of increased uptake with intervening areas of suppression, not a single focal hot spot as seen in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Graves' disease is a common cause of hyperthyroidism. However, it is an autoimmune disorder characterized by TSH receptor antibodies that stimulate the entire gland, leading to a diffusely enlarged goiter and diffuse, symmetric increased uptake on a radioactive iodine scan. This patient has a single nodule and focal uptake. Additionally, the absence of specific signs like exophthalmos and pretibial myxedema makes Graves' disease less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis can manifest with a hyperthyroid phase due to the release of preformed hormone from an inflamed gland. However, patients typically experience significant neck pain and thyroid tenderness, which are absent here. Furthermore, the radioactive iodine uptake would be markedly decreased or absent due to inflammation-induced follicular cell damage, which is the opposite of this patient's scan finding.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of palpitations and weight loss, as well as a decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and an elevated free T4, suggest hyperthyroidism. The radioactive iodine uptake scan shows a single 'hot' nodule.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents for a routine annual examination. She has no specific complaints and reports stable energy levels and weight. Her medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, a 2-cm, firm, non-tender nodule is palpated in the right lobe of her thyroid. The remainder of the thyroid gland feels normal, and no cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test to guide further management of this finding?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The evaluation of a thyroid nodule begins with a measurement of serum TSH to assess the nodule's functional status. This single test is the most important initial step as it determines the subsequent diagnostic pathway. If the TSH is low, it suggests a hyperfunctioning or hot nodule, which is rarely malignant; the next step is a radionuclide thyroid scan. If the TSH is normal or elevated, the nodule is likely non-functioning or cold, carrying a higher risk of malignancy. For these nodules, the next step is a thyroid ultrasound to characterize their features and determine the need for a fine-needle aspiration biopsy. This patient is clinically euthyroid, but TSH measurement is still the essential first step.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum calcitonin is a specific tumor marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), which is a rare type of thyroid cancer. Routine screening for MTC with a calcitonin level in all patients with thyroid nodules is not recommended by US guidelines unless there is a family history of MTC or clinical suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2.

C) INCORRECT:

A radionuclide thyroid scan is used to determine if a nodule is hyperfunctioning (hot) or non-functioning (cold). While it is an important diagnostic tool in the workup of a thyroid nodule, it is not the initial test.

D) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) is the most accurate procedure for evaluating the malignant potential of a thyroid nodule. However, it is not the initial test. Performing FNA before other diagnostic studies could lead to an unnecessary invasive procedure on a hyperfunctioning nodule.

E) INCORRECT:

Thyroglobulin is a protein produced by thyroid follicular cells and can be elevated in many thyroid conditions, both benign and malignant. Because of its lack of specificity, it is not useful for the initial diagnosis of a thyroid nodule. Its primary role is as a tumor marker to monitor for recurrence after thyroidectomy for differentiated thyroid cancer.
questions.hint: The initial evaluation of a thyroid nodule aims to determine if it is functional or nonfunctional, as this will guide the subsequent workup.
